item.title: At Least 6 Killed as Train Derails Outside Paris
item.description: Dozens of others were injured when a crowded passenger train went off the track entering a station in France’s worst train accident in 25 years.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: A derailed carriage at the Brétigny-sur-Orge station on Friday.

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Snowden
item.description: The Lede is following updates on Edward J. Snowden in Moscow, where the first image of him emerged from a meeting with rights groups.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:credit: Tanya Lokshina/Human Rights Watch, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo Airport on Friday, with Sarah Harrison of WikiLeaks at left.

item.title: Blast in Northern Iraq City Kills 19, Officials Say
item.description: Iraqi officials said a bomb exploded inside a crowded coffee shop in Kirkuk, wounding 26.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Spain’s Real Crisis Is a Leadership Void, Analysts Say
item.description: The crisis is hurting national morale and the credibility of institutions, distracting the government from pressing economic concerns, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Lawmakers in Ireland Pass Limited Abortion Bill
item.description: Abortion will be allowed in the Republic of Ireland for the first time after parliament voted to legalize the termination of pregnancies in cases where there is a real and substantial risk to the life of the mother.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: As Uncertainty Reigns Back Home, Many Afghan Envoys Decline to Return
item.description: The diplomatic drain comes amid uncertainty over what conditions will be like in the country after the Western military withdrawal, scheduled to be completed in 2014.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: The Lede: Video of Malala Yousafzai at U.N. Calling on World Leaders to Provide Education to Every Child
item.description: On her 16th birthday, Malala Yousafzai called on world leaders to make education available and compulsory for every child.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Snowden Is Said to Renew Plea for Asylum in Russia
item.description: Edward J. Snowden met with representatives of human rights organizations at his temporary Moscow airport refuge on Friday and appealed for their help in seeking asylum status.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Thousands of Morsi Supporters Rally in Egypt
item.description: The size of the protests underlined the large section of society that has rejected the military intervention that deposed President Mohamed Morsi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Yusuf Sayman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Morsi supporters rallied in the Cairo suburb of Nasr City on Friday.

item.title: Boeing 787 Catches Fire at Heathrow
item.description: The incident, on a plane with no passengers aboard, took place about seven weeks after 787s returned to the skies after being grounded because of hazards with a new type of battery.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: Emergency workers are seen near the tail section of a Boeing 787 that caught fire on Friday at Britain's Heathrow airport, in this image taken from video.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Death Toll at 31 From Flooding in Southwest China
item.description: At least 160 people are still missing from the flooding afflicting a mountainous stretch of Sichuan Province.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: At Least Six Dead as French Train Derails
item.description: At least six people died and several were injured when a regional train derailed en route from Paris to the central city of Limoges, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: A derailed carriage at the French town of Bretigny-sur-Oise on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 12
item.description: Muslims offering prayers at a mosque in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Muslims offering prayers on the first Friday of the holy month of Ramadan at a mosque in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: India Ink: The Buddha Is Smiling in Bodh Gaya
item.description: A writer’s pilgrimage to the Mahabodhi Temple in Bodh Gaya after the recent bomb blasts.
item.dc:creator: By AMITAVA KUMAR
item.media:description: Buddhist monks offering prayers at the Mahabodhi Temple in Bihar on Monday.

item.title: Somalia’s Somewhat Friendly Skies
item.description: Yes, the airline business is taking off in Somalia. Because have you seen the roads?
item.dc:creator: By JOSHUA HAMMER
item.media:credit: Satellite image by DigitalGlobe, via Google Earth
item.media:description: Aden Abdulle International Airport, Mogadishu, September 2011.

item.title: Currents: What Price for Digital Efficiency?
item.description: Technologies like apps that deliver food to your door and order a taxi are making cities nearly frictionless. We may one day begin to miss the old inefficiencies.
item.dc:creator: By ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: Rare Protest in China Against Uranium Plant Draws Hundreds
item.description: The size of the protest in the city of Jiangmen against a uranium processing plant seemed to surprise local officials, who are on the defensive because of safety concerns.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Luxembourg’s Prime Minister Resigns
item.description: Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker, the longest-serving government leader in the European Union, was brought low by an intelligence service scandal.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Dozens of Inmates, Including Terrorists, Flee Indonesian Prison
item.description: About 150 prisoners fled during deadly rioting that started Thursday. About one-third have since been recaptured, and the riot brought under control.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard Thursday at the Tanjung Gusta Penitentiary in Indonesia, which rioting prisoners had set ablaze.

item.title: U.S. Negotiates Expanded Military Role in Philippines
item.description: With the Philippines and China at odds over territorial claims in the Pacific, the United States is stepping up its military support for Manila.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Purported E-Mail From Snowden Asks for Meeting With Rights Groups
item.description: Moscow airport officials say the fugitive American intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden will meet with human rights representatives.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: India Ink: In Kerala, Rehabilitated Killer Nurtures Mentally Challenged
item.description: Albin Mathew, 62, founded Santhi Bhavan Sarvodaya, a shelter for the mentally challenged after serving a jail term for murder.
item.dc:creator: By SHEVLIN SEBASTIAN
item.media:description: Albin Mathew, a reformed murderer and founder of Santhi Bhavan Sarvodaya, a shelter for the mentally challenged in Alappuzha, Kerala.

item.title: National Briefing | Education: Foreign Students Fill Science Ranks at Universities in United States
item.description: International students make up 70 percent of the full-time electrical engineering graduate students, according to a new report by the National Foundation for American Policy.
item.dc:creator: By TAMAR LEWIN

item.title: Ciudad Juárez Weighs a Neglected Notion: Hope
item.description: With a steep decline in violence and a new mayor taking office, there is a guarded sense of a new beginning in a region plagued by crime.
item.dc:creator: By JULIÁN AGUILAR
item.media:credit: Vanessa Monsisvais for The Texas Tribune
item.media:description: Mariachi band members had their shoes shined in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, on Tuesday. There has been a steep decline in violence in the city.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Prisoners Escape in Indonesia
item.description: About 150 prisoners escaped Thursday after they forced their way out from Tanjung Gusta Prison in Medan, the capital of North Sumatra Province.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
